SpNote.note:
For broadband L and M imaging use the following exposure times: Filter Camera Exp,s Obs,s L ' 0.06 0.72 25 512 subarray 0.63 23 full array 0.12 0.18 70 512 subarray 0.21 45 full array M' 0.06 0.45 32 512 subarray 0.12 0.09 96 512 subarray
L and M standards must be observed with identical readout area and exp time due to non-linearity effects
SpNote.title: Exposure times

SpNote.note: We have found that the central 100 pixel wide area of the array, and the low QE bottom right quadrant of the array, do not always subtract cleanly in the thermal. The offset patterns are designed to avoid these areas as far as possible. For the subarray and the nod8 pattern this means using the left (N) side of the array only.
SpNote.title: Offset patterns

SpNote.note: This MSB is incomplete without a standard star in the selected waveband. Since it is not possible to predict the source RA we do not include this standard star here. To get it, file...open the UIST Standards library and drag/drop in the appropriate observations.
SpNote.title: Standards

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky-survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
This example sets up the L' filter with the 0.12"/pixel camera and full 1024x1024 readout.
Select camera or pixel scale from the camera drop down menu.
Select broad or narrowband filter and your choice from the drop down menu. Exposure time and readmode will reset when you change filter!
Readout area is selected from the read mode drop down menu e.g. NDSTARE 1024x1024 or NDSTARE 512x512.
Be careful changing exposure time as the read mode will reset! Refer to the web pages for optimum exposure times in the thermal.
SpNote.title: Configuration information

SpNote.note: If you want to do aperture photometry select NOD_SELF_FLAT_NO_MASK_APHOT
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
If you changed the exposure time in the UIST configuration above, then you must change it for the dark too. The data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time.
Use the reset-to-default button to ensure the dark exposure times for your source and dark are matched.
SpNote.title: change dark exposure time here

SpNote.note: To repeat the nod/jitter pattern more than once on your target, use the repeat item below to specify how many times you want to repeat it.
SpNote.title: how to do more than one nod/jitter set

SpNote.note: The offsets place a set of four observations in each of the top right and lower left quadrants. The lower throughput lower right is avoided. Offsets from center are large enough to avoid sometimes poorly behaved central 100 pixels.
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note: This last offset simply takes the telescope back to 0,0 after all the repeats of the jitter pattern are finished.
SpNote.title: last offset

SpNote.note: This MSB is incomplete without a standard star in the selected waveband. Since it is not possible to predict the source RA we do not include this standard star here. To get it, file...open the UIST Standards library and drag/drop in the appropriate observations.

SpNote.note: For faint targets and broad band filters limit exposure times to 60 seconods to avoid sky variations, except for the 0.06"/pixel camera at J where longer exposures of 100 seconds work well and put you more safely into the background limited regime.
SpNote.title: Exposure times

SpNote.title: offset back to 0,0

SpNote.note: This MSB is incomplete without a standard star in the selected waveband. Since it is not possible to predict the source RA we do not include this standard star here. To get it, file...open the UIST Standards library and drag/drop in the appropriate observations.

SpNote.note:
If you changed the dark exposure time in the UFTI configuration above remember to change it here too.
N.B.: The data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time.
Three darks are done here - one for each filter that will follow. Set the exposure times and co-adds to match those which you will do on the source in each band.
SpNote.title: set dark exposure time here

SpNote.note: To repeat the 5-point jitter pattern more than once for each filter on your target, use the repeat item below to specify how many times you want to repeat it.
SpNote.title: how to do more than one 5-point jitter

SpNote.note: The UIST iteration component below changes filter and exposure time, starting with the setup in the UIST component above. The example here cycles through JHK but any filter set can be selected.
SpNote.title: UIST filter iteration

SpNote.note: This last offset simply takes the telescope back to 0,0 after all the repeats of the jitter pattern are finished.
SpNote.title: last offset

SpNote.note: This MSB is incomplete without a standard star in the selected waveband. Since it is not possible to predict the source RA we do not include this standard star here. To get it, file...open the UIST Standards library and drag/drop in the appropriate observations.

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.

SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
This example sets up the K filter with the 0.12"/pixel camera and full 1024x1024 readout.
Select camera or pixel scale from the camera drop down menu.
Select broad or narrowband filter and your choice from the drop down menu. Exposure time and readmode will reset when you change filter!
Readout area is selected from the read mode drop down menu e.g. NDSTARE 1024x1024 or NDSTARE 512x512.
Be careful changing exposure time as the read mode will reset!
SpNote.title: Configuration information

SpNote.note:
The data-reduction recipe specified below uses the most basic data-reduction recipe for speed. (This is a good idea if your exposure time short.)
If you need to use a more complete recipe then select QUADRANT_JITTER or QUADRANT_JITTER_NO_MASK.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
If you changed the exposure time in the UIST configuration above, then you must change it for the dark too. The data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time.
Use the reset-to-default button to ensure the dark exposure times for your source and dark are matched.
SpNote.title: change dark exposure time here

SpNote.note: To repeat the quadrant pattern more than once on your target, use the repeat item below to specify how many times you want to repeat it.
SpNote.title: how to do more than one quadrant jitter

SpNote.note:
If you want to use a different size of offset, move the highlight to the offset item below and edit them.
Changing the total number of offsets will break the data-reduction recipe.
Quadrant jitters move the source into each quadrant of the array. The flat field is generated for each quadrant by using the data from the frames for which the source was not in that quadrant. This works well for small extended sources.
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note: For convenience this final offset ensures the telescope moves back to 0,0 after all the observations have completed.
SpNote.title: final offset

SpNote.note: This MSB is incomplete without a standard star in the selected waveband. Since it is not possible to predict the source RA we do not include this standard star here. To get it, file...open the UIST Standards library and drag/drop in the appropriate observations.
SpNote.title: Standards

SpNote.note:
Exec for making a map of a large source, < 2 arcmin. Images are taken in strips with semi-random ordering of positions in the strip and of the strip to minimise systematic errors due to sky fluctuations. Sky frames are taken alternately with those of the object.
The offset to "sky" is 150 arcsec. For this offset you can guide at all positions if you are guding on target, or a very nearby star. Otherwise some positions will be "un guided"
It starts with sky then the "middle" frame.
For larger targets see also "extended_5x5".
If speed is an issue, select the simplest form of the recipe, namely EXTENDED_3x3_BASIC.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
This example sets up the K filter with the 0.12"/pixel camera and full 1024x1024 readout.
Select camera or pixel scale from the camera drop down menu.
Select broad or narrowband filter and your choice from the drop down menu. Exposure time and readmode will reset when you change filter!
Readout area is selected from the read mode drop down menu e.g. NDSTARE 1024x1024 or NDSTARE 512x512.
Be careful changing exposure time as the read mode will reset!
SpNote.title: Configuration information

SpNote.note: The data-reduction recipe assumes the order in which the images are taken; if you change this the recipe will not work.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
If you changed the exposure time in the UIST configuration above, then you must change it for the dark too. The data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time.
Use the reset-to-default button to ensure the dark exposure times for your source and dark are matched.
SpNote.title: change dark exposure time here

SpNote.note:
If you want to use a different size of offset, move the highlight to the offset item below and edit them. Most likely this will be location of the "blank sky" region(s), which default to approximately 210 arcseconds north-west and south-east of the target. If there is any doubt concerning the uniformity of the sky, it is better to restrict yourself to one sky region, so that changes in sky level can be measured, and not be attributed to a sky offset between regions. See the IRCAM3 equivalent of this observation for a template.
The target offsets are displaced to give 50% overlap; larger offsets resulting in less than 50% overlap may result in striping in the final mosaic due to different noise levels in the overlap regions.
Changing the total number of offsets will break the data-reduction recipe.
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note: This last offset resets the telescope to 0,0 after all data taking is completed.
SpNote.title: back to 0,0

SpNote.note: This MSB is incomplete without a standard star in the selected waveband. Since it is not possible to predict the source RA we do not include this standard star here. To get it, file...open the UIST Standards library and drag/drop in the appropriate observations.
SpNote.title: Standards

SpNote.note:
Exec for making a map of a large source, < 3 arcmin. Images are taken in strips with semi-random ordering of postions in the strip and of the strip to minimise systematic errors due to sky fluctuations. Sky frames are taken alternately with those of the object.
The offset to "sky" is 180 arcsec. For this offset you can guide at all positions if you are guding on target, or a very nearby star. Otherwise some positions will be "un guided".
It starts with sky then the "middle" frame.
If speed is an issue, select the simplest form of the recipe, namely EXTENDED_5x5_BASIC.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
This example sets up the K filter with the 0.12"/pixel camera and full 1024x1024 readout.
Select camera or pixel scale from the camera drop down menu.
Select broad or narrowband filter and your choice from the drop down menu. Exposure time and readmode will reset when you change filter!
Readout area is selected from the read mode drop down menu e.g. NDSTARE 1024x1024 or NDSTARE 512x512.
Be careful changing exposure time as the read mode will reset!
SpNote.title: Configuration information

SpNote.note: The data-reduction recipe assumes the order in which the images are taken; if you change this the recipe will not work.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
If you changed the exposure time in the UIST configuration above, then you must change it for the dark too. The data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time.
Use the reset-to-default button to ensure the dark exposure times for your source and dark are matched.
SpNote.title: change dark exposure time here

SpNote.note:
If you want to use a different size of offset, move the highlight to the offset item below and edit them. Most likely this will be location of the "blank sky" region(s), which default to approximately 250 arcseconds NW,SE,NE,NW and 3 arcminutes west of the target. If there is any doubt concerning the uniformity of the sky, it is better to restrict yourself to one sky region, so that changes in sky level can be measured, and not be attributed to a sky offset between regions. See the IRCAM3 equivalent of this observation for a template.
The target offsets (the odd-numbered offsets in the iterator below) are displaced to give 50% overlap.
Changing the total number of offsets will break the data-reduction recipe.
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note: This last offset resets the telescope to 0,0 after all data taking is completed.
SpNote.title: back to 0,0

SpNote.note:
Use this observation to make some observations of blank sky which can be processed to generate flat fields. The reduction recipe makes a flat that other reduction recipes can use.
To make more efficient use of telescope time instead of obtaining a flat this way igenerate a flat from an observation of a relatively faint and isolated target.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Select a piece of blank sky near your target.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Choose the appropriate filter and set the exposure time to be at least equal to the background limit time given on the web page
SpNote.title: how to set the exposure time and filter

SpNote.note: This recipe generates a flat field that can be used by other data-reduction recipes. It masks residual stars to reduce artifacts and biases in the flat. If you do not want masking select recipe SKY_FLAT for object observation in the DRRecipe component below.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note:
If you changed the exposure time in the UFTI component then change it for the dark here.
N.B.: The data-reduction recipe will not work unless you have a dark with the right exposure time. Click the reset-to-default button to ensure that your dark exposure time matches that set above.
SpNote.title: change dark exposure time here

SpNote.note: This last offset is to send the telescope back to 0,0 after the observing is finished.
SpNote.title: last offset

SpNote.note:
Observing Poiint Sources ================
There are two MSBs for observing Point Sources; one assumes that the science target is a bright point source which the DR can "find" in the reduced spectral image and display. The second assumes that the science target is faint. In this case, the DR will find the rows containing the standard star and assume that the science target lies on the same rows. These rows will be extracted and displayed. Please bear this in mind when acquiring targets - the standard star and science target should be positioned on the same row AND column (same x-y pixel in imaging acquisition) if the science target is faint.
In both cases, the source is nodded up and down the slit (offset +6" then -6").
Observing Extended Sources ==================
"Extended sources nod to sky" is the default for observing large extended objects. Here, the slit is nodded completely off source so that the target is only on the slit in 50% of the frames.
If, however, the science target is only marginally extended then consider using one of the "extended source slide along slit" MSBs, which are essentially the same as the point source MSB, except that a much larger slide (and a different DR recipe) is used. Slides of up to +30" and -30" are possible.
SpNote.title: Which MSB should I use??

SpNote.note:
For bright calibrators exposures of a few seconds work well.
For faint targets the following exposures are recommended with the 4 pixel slit:
>~300s for IJ, shortJ, longJ, shortH, longH, shortK 240s for HK 60s for shortL 20s for longL 6s for M
SpNote.title: Exposure times

SpNote.note: The default slit PA is -90 so that it matches the UIST imaging orientation (it makes imaging acquisition a bit simpler!), though any angle, between -90 and +90 (measured E of N) can be used.
SpNote.title: Slit position angle

SpNote.note: All targets (bright standards and faint sources) are now acquired in imaging mode. Simply make sure that each observation contains an acquisition Eyeball (see the examples below).
SpNote.title: Acquisition

SpNote.note:
Enter your STANDARD STAR co-ordinates below (this is so that the flat and arc are executed at the location of the standard).
These coordinates will be inherited by the three observations (standard star, target acquisition and target spectroscopy) UNLESS they are over-written by a Target component inside the observation. Obviously, this should be the case for the science target. .
Note - for the standard, you don't need to specify a guide star; the telescope will know to guide on the standard itself.
SpNote.title: Target information - standard

SpNote.note:
This example sets up the HK grism with an east-west 4 pixel slit. Select grism, angle and slit from the drop down menus.
NOTE THAT THE EXPOSURE TIME IS SET FOR THE STANDARD STAR.
These parameters will be inherited by the flat/arc, the standard, and the science target observations. Only the exposure time will be changed (using UIST iterators) for the science target observation.
SpNote.title: Configuration information

SpNote.note: This flat and arc observation will inherit the coordinates and UIST configuration information entered above. In other words, the telescope will slew to the standard, where you can then do the flat and arc before observing the standard itself.
SpNote.title: coords and UIST config

SpNote.note: This standard star observation will inherit the coordinates and UIST configuration information entered above the flat/arc observation.
SpNote.title: coords and UIST config

SpNote.note:
Use the observation below to select a short exposure time for imaging acquisition (depending on the source brightness). For standards, 1 sec should be enough; for faint science targets, 20-30sec is usually ok for point sources down to about 17th mag.
Note about the standard: ================
Chances are, the bright standard will be too bright for imaging acquisition (it may leave a latent image on the array after imaging acquisition). To get around this the TSS will in actual fact acquire a nearby 9-10 mag star. Once this is done, the relative offset between the optical and infrared beams will be calibrated (for on-axis guiding); s/he will then slew back to the brighter standand and, because the standard is also the guide star (again on-axis guiding), simply switching on the guider will put the star down the UIST slit. THIS IS WHY THE BRIGHTESTS SELECTABLE SOURCE MAG FOR TARGET ACQUISITION IS 9TH. SO CHOOSE 9-10 FOR YOUR STANDARD.
SpNote.title: Imaging Acquisition

SpNote.note:
Enter your science target co-ordinates below. When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky-survey picture, examine offset locations on the field, etc.
These coordinates will be used by this observation INSTEAD OF the standard star coordinates entered above.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Science Target information

SpNote.note: Use the observation below to select a short exposure time for imaging acquisition (depending on the source brightness). For standards, 1 sec should be enough; for faint science targets, 20-30sec is usually ok for point sources down to about 17th mag.
SpNote.title: Imaging Acquisition

SpNote.note:
Chances are you will want a longer exposure time on the science target than on the standard.
Use the UIST iterator below to "update" the configuartion set in the main UIST component; only the exposure time and/or coadds should be changed, however. Everything else should be exactly the same (for the flat, arc, standard and science target observations).
If you're not sure about the best exposure time to use, select a source magnitude (first column) and sensible values will appear in the exposure time and coadds columns. If you want a different exposure time, enter these manual. At the end of the day, its the numbers under exposure time and coadds that will be used. Everything else (grism, slit width, slit angle, etc.) will be the same as for the standard star.
SpNote.title: Exp time on science target

SpMSB.title: Faint point source slide along slit

SpNote.note:
Enter your STANDARD STAR co-ordinates below (this is so that the flat and arc are executed at the location of the standard).
These coordinates will be inherited by the three observations (standard star, target acquisition and target spectroscopy) UNLESS they are over-written by a Target component inside the observation. Obviously, this should be the case for the science target. .
Note - for the standard, you don't need to specify a guide star; the telescope will know to guide on the standard itself.
SpNote.title: Target information - standard

SpNote.note:
This example sets up the HK grism with an east-west 4 pixel slit. Select grism, angle and slit from the drop down menus.
NOTE THAT THE EXPOSURE TIME IS SET FOR THE STANDARD STAR.
These parameters will be inherited by the flat/arc, the standard, and the science target observations. Only the exposure time will be changed (using UIST iterators) for the science target observation.
SpNote.title: Configuration information

SpNote.note: This flat and arc observation will inherit the coordinates and UIST configuration information entered above. In other words, the telescope will slew to the standard, where you can then do the flat and arc before observing the standard itself.
SpNote.title: coords and UIST config

SpNote.note: This standard star observation will inherit the coordinates and UIST configuration information entered above the flat/arc observation.
SpNote.title: coords and UIST config

SpNote.note:
Use the observation below to select a short exposure time for imaging acquisition (depending on the source brightness). For standards, 1 sec should be enough; for faint science targets, 20-30sec is usually ok for point sources down to about 17th mag.
Note about the standard: ================
Chances are, the bright standard will be too bright for imaging acquisition (it may leave a latent image on the array after imaging acquisition). To get around this the TSS will in actual fact acquire a nearby 9-10 mag star. Once this is done, the relative offset between the optical and infrared beams will be calibrated (for on-axis guiding); s/he will then slew back to the brighter standand and, because the standard is also the guide star (again on-axis guiding), simply switching on the guider will put the star down the UIST slit. THIS IS WHY THE BRIGHTESTS SELECTABLE SOURCE MAG FOR TARGET ACQUISITION IS 9TH. SO CHOOSE 9-10 FOR YOUR STANDARD.
SpNote.title: Imaging Acquisition

SpNote.note:
Enter your science target co-ordinates below. When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky-survey picture, examine offset locations on the field, etc.
These coordinates will be used by this observation INSTEAD OF the standard star coordinates entered above.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Science Target information

SpNote.note: Use the observation below to select a short exposure time for imaging acquisition (depending on the source brightness). For standards, 1 sec should be enough; for faint science targets, 20-30sec is usually ok for point sources down to about 17th mag.
SpNote.title: Imaging Acquisition

SpNote.note:
If you will be using long Movie-mode exposures for imaging acquisition then in subsequent frames you may get fairly high residual signal (1% level) on the array - and high associated noise - which may "compromise" your faint-target spectroscopy. To clear this residual signal, use the 1sec darks below. These will be used to "flush" the array after target acquisition, but before spectra are taken.
If residuals aren't likely to interfere with your spectra then you should delete the line (the darks) below - i.e. highligh this line and click on "Cut".
NB - don't click on default in the darks - 1sec is best for flushing...
SpNote.title: Flush array (optional)

SpNote.note:
Chances are you will want a longer exposure time on the science target than on the standard.
Use the UIST iterator below to "update" the configuartion set in the main UIST component; only the exposure time and/or coadds should be changed, however. Everything else should be exactly the same (for the flat, arc, standard and science target observations).
If you're not sure about the best exposure time to use, select a source magnitude (first column) and sensible values will appear in the exposure time and coadds columns. If you want a different exposure time, enter these manual. At the end of the day, its the numbers under exposure time and coadds that will be used. Everything else (grism, slit width, slit angle, etc.) will be the same as for the standard star.
SpNote.title: Exp time on science target

SpNote.note:
Enter your STANDARD STAR co-ordinates below (this is so that the flat and arc are executed at the location of the standard).
These coordinates will be inherited by the three observations (standard star, target acquisition and target spectroscopy) UNLESS they are over-written by a Target component inside the observation. Obviously, this should be the case for the science target. .
Note - for the standard, you don't need to specify a guide star; the telescope will know to guide on the standard itself.

Once this is done, the relative offset between the optical and infrared beams will be calibrated (for on-axis guiding); s/he will then slew back to the brighter standand and, because the standard is also the guide star (again on-axis guiding), simply switching on the guider will put the star down the UIST slit. SpNote.title: Imaging Acquisition

SpNote.note:
Enter your science target co-ordinates below. When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky-survey picture, examine offset locations on the field, etc.
These coordinates will be used by this observation INSTEAD OF the standard star coordinates entered above.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Science Target information

SpNote.note: Use the observation below to select a short exposure time for imaging acquisition (depending on the source brightness). For standards, 1 sec should be enough; for faint science targets, 20-30sec is usually ok for point sources down to about 17th mag.
SpNote.title: Imaging Acquisition

SpNote.note:
If your target is likely to be bright when running Movie in imaging acquisition mode, it may leave a residual feature (at the 1% level) in subsequent spectroscopy frames. If these are likely to interfere with the spectra from your extended target, then leave the five 1sec darks in the next line. These will be used to "flush" the array after target acquisition, but before spectra are taken.
If residuals aren't likely to interfere with your spectra (e.g. because the target is faint and/or the offsets will move the spectra away from the location of the source in imaging acquisition), then you should delete the line (the darks) below - i.e. highligh this line and click on "Cut".
NB - don't click on default in the darks - 1sec is best for flushing...
SpNote.title: Flush array (optional)

SpNote.note:

If you want a different exposure time, enter these manual. At the end of the day, its the numbers under exposure time and coadds that will be used. Everything else (grism, slit width, slit angle, etc.) will be the same as for the standard star.
SpNote.title: Exp time on science target

SpNote.note:
Chances are you will want a longer exposure time on the science target than on the standard.
Use the UIST iterator below to "update" the configuartion set in the main UIST component; only the exposure time and/or coadds should be changed, however. Everything else should be exactly the same (for the flat, arc, standard and science target observations).
If you're not sure about the best exposure time to use, select a source magnitude (first column) and sensible values will appear in the exposure time and coadds columns. If you want a different exposure time, enter these manual. At the end of the day, its the numbers under exposure time and coadds that will be used. Everything else (grism, slit width, slit angle, etc.) will be the same as for the standard star.
SpNote.title: Exp time on science target

SpNote.note:
Observing Extended Sources ==================
"IFU nod to blank sky" is the default for observing small, extended objects. Here, the 3.3"x6.0" IFU field-of-view is nodded completely off source so that the target is only on the IFU in 50% of the frames.
"IFU map extended source" demonstrates how the IFU may be mapped across a more extended target.
If the science target is only very slightly extended (almost a point source) then it might be worth trying to slide the sourtce within the IFU field (edit the offsets accordingly; q is along the IFU 6" long axis). However, note that the avaiable field is only 6" long, so it might not be worth the risk, especially for standards where only a small fraction of your observing time will be used on the extra blank skies!
SpNote.title: Which MSB should I use??

SpNote.note:
For bright calibrators exposures of a few seconds work well.
For faint targets the following exposures are recommended with the IFU+2-pixel slit:
>~300s for IJ, shortJ, longJ, shortH, longH, shortK, long-K, HK ~60s for shortL ~20s for longL ~6s for M
SpNote.title: Exposure times

SpNote.note: The default IFU PA is -90 so that it matches the UIST imaging orientation (it makes imaging acquisition a bit simpler!), though any angle, between -90 and +90 (measured E of N) can be used.
SpNote.title: IFU long-axis position angle

SpNote.note: All targets (bright standards and faint sources) are now acquired in imaging mode. Simply make sure that each observation contains an acquisition Eyeball (see the examples below).
SpNote.title: Acquisition

SpNote.note:
Enter your STANDARD STAR co-ordinates below (this is so that the flat and arc are executed at the location of the standard).
These coordinates will be inherited by the three observations (standard star, target acquisition and target spectroscopy) UNLESS they are over-written by a Target component inside the observation. Obviously, this should be the case for the science target. .
Note - for the standard, you don't need to specify a guide star; the telescope will know to guide on the standard itself.
SpNote.title: Target information - standard

SpNote.note:
This example sets up the HK grism with the IFU orientated E-W. Select grism, angle, etc. the drop down menus.
NOTE THAT THE EXPOSURE TIME IS SET FOR THE STANDARD STAR.
These parameters will be inherited by the flat/arc, the standard, and the science target observations. Only the exposure time will be changed (using UIST iterators) for the science target observation.
SpNote.title: Configuration information

SpNote.title: coords and UIST config

SpNote.note: This standard star observation will inherit the coordinates and UIST configuration information entered above the flat/arc observation.
SpNote.title: coords and UIST config

SpNote.note:
Use the observation below to select a short exposure time for imaging acquisition (depending on the source brightness). For standards, 1 sec should be enough; for faint science targets, 20-30sec is usually ok for point sources down to about 17th mag.
Note about the standard: ================
Chances are, the bright standard will be too bright for imaging acquisition (it may leave a latent image on the array after imaging acquisition). To get around this the TSS will in actual fact acquire a nearby 9-10 mag star. Once this is done, the relative offset between the optical and infrared beams will be calibrated (for on-axis guiding); s/he will then slew back to the brighter standand and, because the standard is also the guide star (again on-axis guiding), simply switching on the guider will put the star down the UIST slit. THIS IS WHY THE BRIGHTEST SELECTABLE SOURCE MAG FOR TARGET ACQUISITION IS 9TH. SO CHOOSE 9-10 FOR YOUR STANDARD.
SpNote.title: Imaging Acquisition

SpNote.note:
If your target is likely to be bright when running Movie in imaging acquisition mode, it may leave a residual feature (at the 1% level) in subsequent spectroscopy frames. If these are likely to interfere with the spectra from your extended target, then leave the five 1sec darks in the next line. These will be used to "flush" the array after target acquisition, but before spectra are taken.
If residuals aren't likely to interfere with your spectra (e.g. because the target is faint), then you should delete the line (the darks) below - i.e. highligh this line and click on "Cut".
NB - don't click on default in the darks - 1sec is best for flushing...
SpNote.title: Flush array (optional)

SpNote.note:
If you want offsets to sky of less than 30 arcsec it is essential that observation types are set to OBJECT and SKY so that the data reduction software can identify sky frames. In this case you will have to use an offset iterator for every position, each containing just an OBJECT or a SKY observe.
Note: p and q are perpendicular to and along the IFU long axis.
SpNote.title: IFU offsets

SpObs.title: Science target -- nod to blank sky

SpNote.note:
Enter your science target co-ordinates below. When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky-survey picture, examine offset locations on the field, etc.
These coordinates will be used by this observation INSTEAD OF the standard star coordinates entered above.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Science Target information

SpNote.note: Use the observation below to select a short exposure time for imaging acquisition (depending on the source brightness). For standards, 1 sec should be enough; for faint science targets, 20-30sec is usually ok for point sources down to about 17th mag.
SpNote.title: Imaging Acquisition

SpNote.note:
If your target is likely to be bright when running Movie in imaging acquisition mode, it may leave a residual feature (at the 1% level) in subsequent spectroscopy frames. If these are likely to interfere with the spectra from your extended target, then leave the five 1sec darks in the next line. These will be used to "flush" the array after target acquisition, but before spectra are taken.
If residuals aren't likely to interfere with your spectra (e.g. because the target is faint), then you should delete the line (the darks) below - i.e. highligh this line and click on "Cut".
NB - don't click on default in the darks - 1sec is best for flushing...
SpNote.title: Flush array (optional)

SpNote.note:
Chances are you will want a longer exposure time on the science target than on the standard.
Use the UIST iterator below to "update" the configuartion set in the main UIST component; only the exposure time and/or coadds should be changed, however. Everything else should be exactly the same (for the flat, arc, standard and science target observations).
If you're not sure about the best exposure time to use, select a source magnitude (first column) and sensible values will appear in the exposure time and coadds columns. If you want a different exposure time, enter these manual. At the end of the day, its the numbers under exposure time and coadds that will be used. Everything else (grism, ifu angle, etc.) will be the same as for the standard star.
SpNote.title: Exp time on science target

SpNote.note:
If you want offsets to sky of less than 30 arcsec it is essential that observation types are set to OBJECT and SKY so that the data reduction software can identify sky frames. In this case you will have to use an offset iterator for every position, each containing just an OBJECT or a SKY observe.
Note: p and q are perpendicular to and along the IFU long axis.
SpNote.title: IFU offsets

SpNote.note:
Enter your STANDARD STAR co-ordinates below (this is so that the flat and arc are executed at the location of the standard).
These coordinates will be inherited by the three observations (standard star, target acquisition and target spectroscopy) UNLESS they are over-written by a Target component inside the observation. Obviously, this should be the case for the science target. .
Note - for the standard, you don't need to specify a guide star; the telescope will know to guide on the standard itself.
SpNote.title: Target information - standard

SpNote.note:
This example sets up the HK grism with the IFU orientated E-W. Select grism, angle, etc. the drop down menus.
NOTE THAT THE EXPOSURE TIME IS SET FOR THE STANDARD STAR.
These parameters will be inherited by the flat/arc, the standard, and the science target observations. Only the exposure time will be changed (using UIST iterators) for the science target observation.
SpNote.title: Configuration information

SpNote.note: This flat and arc observation will inherit the coordinates and UIST configuration information entered above. In other words, the telescope will slew to the standard, where you can then do the flat and arc before observing the standard itself.
SpNote.title: coords and UIST config

SpNote.note: This standard star observation will inherit the coordinates and UIST configuration information entered above the flat/arc observation.
SpNote.title: coords and UIST config

SpNote.title: Exp time on science target

SpNote.note: To map larger areas, simply add offsets into the list in the offset iterator below.
SpNote.title: IFU offsets
